Vector addition: two or more vectors can be added by combining their corresponding components.
Vector subtraction: two vectors can be subtracted by subtracting their corresponding components.
Scalar multiplication: a vector can be scaled by multiplying each component by a scalar.
Dot product (also known as the inner product): two vectors can be multiplied together to produce a scalar value.
Vector magnitude (also known as the norm or length): the distance of a vector from the origin.
Vector length (also known as the magnitude): the distance of a vector from the origin.
Unit vector: a vector with a magnitude of 1.
Orthogonal vectors: two vectors that are perpendicular to each other.
Linearly independent vectors: a set of vectors that cannot be expressed as a linear combination of each other.
Matrix addition: two or more matrices can be added by combining their corresponding elements.
Matrix multiplication: two matrices can be multiplied together to produce another matrix.
Matrix transpose: the transpose of a matrix is obtained by interchanging its rows and columns.
Matrix determinant: a scalar value that can be used to determine the invertibility of a matrix.
Linear transformation: a transformation that preserves the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication.
Invertible linear transformation: a linear transformation that has an inverse.
Isomorphism: a bijective linear transformation between two vector spaces.
Eigenvalue: a scalar value that represents how much a linear transformation stretches or shrinks a vector.
Eigenvector: a non-zero vector that, when multiplied by a linear transformation, results in a scaled version of itself.
Diagonalization: a process of finding a basis of eigenvectors for a linear transformation.
Orthogonalization: a process of converting a set of vectors into an orthonormal basis.
Gram-Schmidt process: a method for orthogonalizing a set of vectors.
Linear independence: a set of vectors that cannot be expressed as a linear combination of each other.
Span: the set of all linear combinations of a set of vectors.
Rank: the maximum number of linearly independent vectors in a set.
Nullity: the dimension of the null space of a linear transformation.
Basis: a set of linearly independent vectors that span a vector space.
Dimension: the number of vectors in a basis.
Inner product space: a vector space equipped with an inner product.
Hermitian matrix: a square matrix that is equal to its own conjugate transpose.
Positive definite matrix: a Hermitian matrix that is always positive semi-definite.
SVD: a factorization of a matrix into three matrices: U, Σ, and V.
Singular value decomposition: a process of decomposing a matrix into its singular values, left singular vectors, and right singular vectors.
Detailed explanations of the mathematical definitions and formulas for each concept.
Relationships between different concepts (e.g., how eigenvalues relate to diagonalization).
Examples and applications of each concept.
More advanced topics, such as:
Linear algebra in higher dimensions (e.g., 3D, 4D).
Linear algebra and other mathematical fields (e.g., calculus, differential equations).
Applications of linear algebra in fields like physics, engineering, and computer science.
Advanced linear algebra techniques (e.g., Jordan canonical form, Schur decomposition).
Clarification on the differences between various types of matrices (e.g., symmetric, skew-symmetric, Hermitian).

Comparison with other mathematical structures (e.g., groups, rings, fields).

Linear algebra and optimization (e.g., linear programming, eigenvalue decomposition).
Linear algebra and differential equations (e.g., eigenvalue analysis, Lyapunov stability).
Linear algebra and numerical analysis (e.g., numerical linear algebra, eigenvalue computation).
